function_call.name: get_risks
function_call.arguments: {"risks":[{"Description":"Utilizing a small sample size of 97 subjects may lead to a lack of generalizability of the findings.","Impact":"The findings may not accurately represent the larger population and may lead to misguided interventions or policies.","Mitigation":"Increase the sample size or use statistical techniques to account for the small sample size.","Technologies":"Statistical analysis software for power calculation and sample size determination.","People":"Research participants, policymakers, and organizations utilizing the survey results.","Owner":"Researchers, statisticians, and funding organizations."},{"Description":"Collecting survey responses during the COVID-19 pandemic may introduce bias due to the impact of the pandemic on respondents' perspectives and behaviors.","Impact":"The survey results may not accurately reflect the pre-pandemic or post-pandemic conditions, leading to skewed insights.","Mitigation":"Include specific questions addressing the pandemic's influence and analyze data with pandemic-related variables as covariates.","Technologies":"Online survey platforms with customizable questionnaires.","People":"Survey respondents, data analysts, and decision-makers using the survey results.","Owner":"Researchers, survey administrators, and organizations utilizing the survey data."},{"Description":"Using a cross-sectional approach may overlook the dynamic nature of the COVID-19 situation, leading to limited insights into longitudinal changes.","Impact":"The findings may not capture how the impacts of COVID-19 evolve over time, limiting the understanding of long-term effects.","Mitigation":"Combine cross-sectional data with longitudinal studies or follow-up surveys to track changes over time.","Technologies":"Longitudinal data analysis software, survey tracking platforms.","People":"Research participants, data analysts, and policymakers interpreting the survey results.","Owner":"Researchers, data collection teams, and organizations funding longitudinal studies."}]}
